cloudbaseinit/utils/windows/netlbfo.py.message: Since we're trying to make this less flaky, I would also take a look at this: Why doesn't the team get created? .put returns an error code / return code, so we should also see what it is or what it means. An exception could also be raised here if needed.

During my tests there were no real errors during put(). The team just didn't get created and failed during _wait_for_nic(). My guess is that the necessary WMI providers were not yet up and running at the time of the attempt, and no real errors were exposed during creation. It silently failed.

Retrying the self._create_team() function didn't work either. A new WMI connection was needed, hence the retry decorator directly on the create_team() function.

This depends on the netlbfo implementation in Windows which we cannot control. it also varies depending on the Windows version or the network card hardware -- the problem is that this call does not fail even if the team is not created, that is why we have those retries. empirical results show that this call is implemented in asynchronous way, as it passes more than one layer: mi, netlbfo, network driver and back.

deploy-guide/source/upgrade-overview.rst.message: I don't think "Ideally" and "ill-advised" fit in here. I think the words we choose here should be more definitive and simply state that operating clouds with components from different releases is not tested or supported.

I don't really think it is viable to upgrade OpenStack every 6 months on a production cloud.  I suspect that really, it's "go for the latest release on the Ubuntu LTS and then upgrade when you need new features or a new Ubuntu LTS".  We might have to start thinking about how upgrades are done from LTS to LTS.

I'd agree with Alex that its extremely unlike that any one will be upgrading every 6 months. In practice, the driving factors for upgrades are around support lifetimes and feature requirements. Upgrades also happen to be somewhat painful and disruptive and tends to lead towards people not wanting to upgrade more frequently.

I'd be in favor of striking the every six months upgrade commentary and simply talking about how to upgrade between the various releases. While it would be ideal, its unfortunate that it won't really be done in practice.

On the LTS to LTS front, the supported way to do that today is to upgrade through the various intermediate releases until you hit the next crossover release. Anything else is out of scope for now.

One still needs to upgrade, N+1 fashion, through OpenStack releases though right? I can either double down on the idealised scenario (every six months) or say "upgrade to the next OpenStack release when you want as long as it is within the support window".

I'm not sure what you mean by "start thinking about how upgrades are done from LTS to LTS".

The problem is that nobody running this stuff (even us) upgrades every six months.  It tends to be that if it is working, it gets left working.  So the only reason to upgrade is to fix something or get a new feature.  We support upgrades so that people can do that.  I'd just remove the idea that "normally" you upgrade, I think.

The LTS to LTS issue, is that we do recommend that people upgrade ubuntu LTS to the next one when it comes out.  Thus, realistically, we ought to have some way of also taking openstack with that.  However, it's a mess, and we shouldn't talk about that here, I guess.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: Could you elaborate please?
Of course
so what's the main issue with giving GIL to other greenthreads during polling cycle? Sorry for bothering, just want to understand what is fixed here.
I'm generally ok with change but would like to see info asked by Oleg.

The main issue is that the cycle operation is interrupted. For example, if you are adding a set of new ports or updating the SGs. The L2 population driver introduces, in system with a high amount of ports, continue interruptions in the normal port processing.

Any callback from an RPC call (those are the interruptions we have in the OVS agent) should be attended at the end of the cycle, not in the middle of a batch processing. Any updated information processing about any port should be delayed to the next iteration.

One reason for letting other greenthreads a chance is to make agent more responsive during restarts for example, when it needs to process a large set of ports. Otherwise new resources creation could fail during that time.

ok, I understant what issue Rodolfo is trying to improve now. We have seen that already at our customer's - when they were using l2_population and spawning many ports - agent was overloaded and took very long time to provision ports as it was most of the time doing l2_population related things.

There is no ideal solution there but maybe we can try with that new way now :)
Done

I think this may need a more specific definition.

OpenStack services per-se are not high available, but they aim to have certain features that makes it possible to be deployed in a high available fashion. Testing that does not necessarily require an high-available deployment. For instance checking that API services are stateless can be tested by restarting the service in a one node deployment. 

The other thing that you may want to test is that your deployment is high available / resilient to failure to the expected degree. This in fact is a test that your deployment / lifecycle tool of choice and your configuration management tools and your configuration are doing the right thing. 

So these tests would probably be interesting ones for openstack-ansible, puppet, kolla & friends.

However we do not necessarily test calls to specific APIs in parallel. I imagine this kind of testing might be something like issue a number of create/update/delete for a specific resource in "parallel" and verify that the end result is what expected. 

The spec [0] talks about using Rally for this concurrent testing, but here you talk about load injection - which is a different thing. Are you thinking about load testing or concurrent testing or injecting APIs in the system while running HA scenarios?
Nice. A driver model is probably what we need since HA tests are very much deployment specific - a lot of what they test is the deployment itself in fact.

Could you please add Jepsen [0] framework to alternatives?

[0] https://github.com/jepsen-io/jepsen

One of the challenges of HA / resiliency testing is the fact that many different things need to happen in parallel: generate traffic on the system while injecting failures while probing the status.

I wonder if the choice of a linear approach is the best for this case. I see the value in having re-usable "bricks" of tests to combine together but not necessarily in their strict sequential execution.

It depends on the granularity of the bricks/steps. 

For Pacemaker we have a series of tests (such as start/stop/kill a node/service) that were executed at random.  Sometimes these tests were combined, ie. a restart test wrapped the stop and start tests. 

Each test has pre and post conditions, but were definitely linear internally and validated progress at appropriate points.  Was each test a brick or a sequence of steps? 

Ultimately you need elements of both.

I think it make sense for having some of this type of testing happening on single services - however I expect there will be the need for integration type of tests where we prove HA / resiliency to failure in a full cloud scenario.
If the service tests had predictable entry points (eg. ${service} start/stop/kill/status), then a higher level test could wrap them for use in more wholistic tests.
Please wrap long lines, otherwise they are hard to review in Gerrit, and more likely to result in merge conflicts.

But it's Open Source, so doesn't it make sense to extend it to encompass the extra functionality you need, instead of starting from scratch?  There are strong disadvantages to starting from scratch, e.g. it wastes time required to reimplement the same things, and it fragments a community which is already stretched thin on resources.

If there are deal-breaker reasons why os-faults can't be used here (e.g. an architectural mismatch, or you've talked to the os-faults maintainers about extending the functionality and they refused to accept that direction) then please give details. Otherwise I'm afraid it makes this decision sound like NIH syndrome, and I'm sure that's not your intention.

Is there a discussion on a mailing list somewhere about this, which can be linked to?

I have some observations after trying out destructive testing in fairly large OpenStack environments. Not sure I want to put all these in a review here. But in summary:

1. os-faults basically adds environment discovery, failure injection and a CLI and wraps them around Ansible programmatically. From my experience that's been too much code to write when extending the failures. What I've been using is Ansible playbooks and dynamic inventories.

2. Programmatic invocation of Ansible means we have to always keep up with Ansible internals. 

3. os-faults does provide some randomization around which nodes in a group to hit. E.g. you can say hit keystone and it will take a random keystone service out. But, this is easily done by creating Ansible strategy plugins as well.

In short, while os-faults was easy to start off with I essentially fell back to just using playbooks, dynamic inventories and custom created strategy plugins to randomize hits on targets. This approach has also made some of my modules reusable for the tenant space as well - e.g. I can use an Ansible module to hard-reboot a tenant VM by just using a different dynamic inventory (e.g. the OpenStack Ansible dynamic inventory script).

The discussion can of course take place on the mailing lists and IRC, but I am also intending to organise a video call to kickstart collaboration between interested parties across the whole community:

mtce/src/heartbeat/hbsClient.cpp.message: Just wondering whether a failure to set the socket to non-blocking should be a fatal error instead? Why would we expect that this might fail and that would be OK?

Adding non-blocking attribute to this socket is new.

This daemon has been working just fine without it since day one. The read from the socket is only based on select fd being set indicating there is something to receive.

There has been no specific issue traced to it being blocking. This update is implemented in response to a 'speculative suggestion' and now you are suggesting that not being able to set it non-blocking, which should never happen, should be treated as a critical fault now.

I can make the change but it seems unnecessary given there is a warning log stating it could not be set.
If you can provide an argument for discussion of why a failure to set non blocking should fail the node then I'll make the change.

As you say, setting the socket to non-blocking should never fail. So if it fails, it is likely due to a software bug that needs to be fixed, so I prefer to make it a hard failure which can't be ignored (logs can be and often are ingored). Just my preference though.

I think _whatever the consumption model_, we want to make sure it's easy to consume with minimum dependencies.
Yeah, this seems unrelated.

Agree, although one use case for a standalone service is running it in a containerized environment, it's not the only one.

Swift has arguably been useful from the beginning as a standalone service, before docker was invented.
Thank you for the feedback. I will remove this requirement.
Wording here is odd.  Would say "which services these are in order to consider their adoption."
without?
Yeah, I'm leaning on removing this entirely, given that this requirement is already covered by the project being under OpenStack governance in the first place.

The "without" is already covered by the first requirement. This is to have the service still primarily focus on being an OpenStack service first. Do you have ideas for better wording or do you think this point is unnecessary?

Yes, it was just confusing to me. I would remove the phrase.

Or rephrase, by making an emphasis on the fact it can _still_ run as a non-standlone:

`The service can still behave properly with other OpenStack services, without any loss of their expected (integration) functionalities.` ?

At the scale of 100,000 nodes, say 15% encounter a transitory issue a day, 15,000 nodes... two entires per node, 30,000 events...

30,000 events

((4 * 2 Bytes) + ( 36 +1 Bytes) + 4 Bytes + (estimating 64+1 Bytes) + (estimating 32 + 1 Bytes) + (1k + 2 Bytes)+ 4 Bytes (I think that is what ends up in memory for text fields))

1177 Bytes per record

 30,000 nodes * 1177 Bytes * 7 days = 247,170,000 bytes on disk in a memory mapped file...
... which means if the memory pressure is strong enough it will start reading blocks into the cache per node.

That seems like a performance/memory impact for the large scale operators.

Let's also think if RDBMS like MySQL is actually a good for this kind of data. In my past we kept this stuff in Redis, which has built-in TTL (without vacuuming issues on bulk-deletion). Of course it wouldn't be wise to keep the whole messages in Redis, but.. maybe we don't need to? After all, that's what logs are for?

Maybe we could provide only the base clues for the operators, like "Yesterday at 14:15 UTC a power fault happened and got recovered at 14:45". Then they can dive into whatever tool for logs crunching they have to see more context. After all, there specialized solutions for that, maybe we shouldn't duplicate their job?

And thinking more about that, shouldn't we rely on some 3rd party solutions for the whole feature? In the same past we used Redis like that: for quick overview of recent events. Then we could dive into a specialized tool.

> Just thinking through the numbers, because I suspect this should be
 > seconds.

Typically we keep records for a week, that's how 7 days come into play. I don't think this feature would make sense for keeping such a short period. A node fails and when we check its history, I can't imagine it's gone \o/

it's important to have two APIs here, but I think this misses the mark slightly:
1. list of all events in the history, likely paginated because the event log could be very long
2. full details for a single event

My general preference in designing APIs is for a "?detail" parameter to be optional on the "list" call, which causes the API to include full details of the events rather than either mere IDs or ID+summary, for the events within the pagination range being returned, and for this not to be the default.

in this way, the default client experience avoids being overwhelmed when there is a lot more data than expected.

I feel like we would still have a summary field that provides short info on the error and return by default, if the consumer needs details, it can do a full query with fields or with detail=true.
The fact is not all events are important, experienced operator may only need to check a few related events.
I agree, pagination and details querying are also adopted in other api resources, we can just follow existing pattern.

One thing we may want to do is enable an operator to set a limit on the number of rows purged by the periodic task at a time. Specifically because Deleting a thousand or ten thousand rows on a table can lock the table for a while.

It may not be something easily supported by sqlalchemy, but something to consider because bulk cleanups can be very impacting. I once had 13 million events and only needed about 500,000 of them. Batch update wise I could get like 130,000 an hour and block the entire monitoring system, or I could get like a hundred every five minutes. It took a while, but the DB was eventually back to a sane size.
We absolutely need to remove information in batches, even for 7 days we can generate quite a lot if we have thousands of nodes.

It's out of my expectation for this amount of events, but *shrugs* because by default we keep records for 7 days.
Maybe we could reduce the default ttl, but we don't know what value users perfer in reality :(

nodepool/builder.py.message:
I think we should think about the placement of this block as there are different possibilities with different advantages/disadvantages.

_buildImage (here):

* we already have the lock and the image build object in zk
* possibly high turnaround frequency in zk
* high visibility of failed builds (appear in dib-image-list)
* possibly confusing or the operator since there is no build log for a failed build in the dib-image-list
* confusing for the user who looks at the dib-image-list web endpoint. This point can act as a ticket generator in our case even if there are other builders that can build the image.


_checkImageForManualBuildRequest and _checkImageForScheduledImageUpdates:

* avoid lock and image build object -> builder just ignores it
* less traffic on zk
* low visibility of this condition (error logs)
* less confusing since there is no mismatch of failed image build with missing build log


All in all I think I'd tend slightly to the second option despite less visibility (that's still in the error log of each builder) due to the user confusion point which could get problematic or us.
I tend to agree with that.  I also think we should have some back-off; like not try again for 2 minutes.  I'll try to rework it

How will a node define what Ceph services are needed for a node role?

Roles like "Controller" in TripleO have this services defined
in their environment definition [1], so nothing is going to 
change here.
Same for DCN related roles [2] [3] [4].
According to the 'ServicesDefault' we're supposed to find that
service in that node, following the classic TripleO deployment
flow (as well as in DCN context).
IMHO the flow here is the same that works with ceph-ansible.
We continue to use the same inventory, and from tht, where
the variables are generated, we continue triggering a role
which is able to deploy Ceph [5].
The difference is that we're going to include a playbook defined
in the 'tripleo-ceph' project instead of ceph-ansible.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/roles/Controller.yaml#L52-L57
[2] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/roles/DistributedComputeHCI.yaml
[3] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/roles/DistributedComputeHCIScaleOut.yaml
[4] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/roles/DistributedComputeScaleOut.yaml
[5] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/deployment/ceph-ansible/ceph-base.yaml#L653-L655
What is release mechanism for openstack/tripleo-ceph release? is it still part of TripleO or a separately released entity?
Still a part of TripleO but in a separate repository.
isn't that required for both proposals: original and alternative? And how HW is configured maybe be different depending on HW components and  node role?
The servers could also be pre-provisioned. Because metalsmith is not necessary I'll simply change this part to "deploy hardware".

what happens with bootstrap nodes after deployment?
What happens on failure of the bootstrap node?

That bootstap node is the first ceph monitor. After deployment it stays in service. A ceph-ansible deployment works the same way. One of the hosts with the CephMon service is used as the first ceph-mon and the ceph cluster is started on it and then other nodes are added.

If the bootstrap process fails then the deployment stops the same way it does if ceph-ansible has an error.
assume there is no dependency on original bootstrap node.
No. It's just the first ceph mon and ceph mons can be replaced.

If it OSD as a service then yes.

As mentioned @PTG, I think the alternative to creating roles that are invoked via THT (e.g. the existing method), would be to move the management of ceph outside of the `openstack overcloud deploy` process.  As outlined, it would be something like...

1) `openstack overcloud node provision`
2) network configuration needs to be executed. (Currently proposed effort as part of network config v2)
3) ceph provision executed against provisioned nodes
4) `openstack overcloud deploy` run with inputs from node provisioning and ceph processes.

This allows the management of ceph to continue to be collocated with the tripleo nodes, but allows for proper separation for updates/upgrades/etc.

Instead of saying outside vs inside of TripleO I should be saying before or during overcloud deployment. When this spec is implemented, Ceph will not be configured when 'openstack overcloud deploy' but the Ceph deployment remains a part of TripleO. The change is that the Ceph deployment is decoupled from the overcloud deployment. By decoupling we reduce complexity. It fits the same pattern as PXE'ing the servers outside of the overcloud deployment by using metalsmith.

In the next patchset lines 98-117 will make this more clear. Thanks for the suggestion.

The fact is that some TripleO configurations (firewalls, Haproxy, TLS and cert generation) rely on the overcloud deployment flow.
This means that you can split the "provisioning" aspect of Ceph (when cephadm is triggered), but during the overcloud deployment some tht are still needed to provide values and info to ensure a fully supported integration and avoid breaking existing features

This is an issue with transitioning the ownership of services away from tripleo.  If tripleo owns the firewall, it owns the whole thing and assumes it's managed in such a way.  In order for the firewalls to be properly owned, you'd still have to tell tripleo which ports need to be open on which roles in order for the rules to properly be applied on the correct hosts. We do have an extra rules variable that could be used but would need to be merged with any customer's values.  It reduces the overall usefullness of letting ceph deploy bits. You could create dummy ceph services that can be used to handle the firewall/haproxy integration and not actually do any "deployment" actions.

What about adding new nodes to Ceph cluster?

The same 2 step process defined below but now part of day 2 operation.

Yes, the process of scaling up/down is tied to TripleO.
If step-2 process:
* before any ansible run we should provision and provide the new resources using metalsmith and then we should be able to place them within the Ceph cluster applying the related Ceph Spec.

If step-4 process:
* same story, metalsmith should provide the new hw, the network should be configured and then we can add the new node using the Ceph spec applied to cephadm.

The difference between the 2-step and 4-step approach is that in the first case the process of scaling-up the ceph cluster happens using the `overcloud deploy command`, instead in the 4-step approach the Ceph spec can be applied (and passed) using the provisioning command.
Heat will not be the single source of truth for Ceph, and the status of the cluster is maintained by cephadm, for this reason after provisioning the new hw and setting up the network, cephadm should be triggered to add the new resources to the Ceph cluster.

As per line 538 of PS 35:

- Node scale up operations for day2 Ceph should be done by running
  `openstack overcloud node provision` and then `openstack overcloud
  ceph ...`. If that operation includes adding hyperconvernged node
  with both Ceph and OpenStack services then the third step will be to
  run `openstack overcloud deploy`.

So you:

1. add the node with metalsmith (openstack overcloud node provision)
2. configure networking (openstack overcloud network ...)
3. add the node to the ceph cluster (openstack overcloud ceph provision)
4. optionally: if HCI, then add compute containers to the same node 

For step 3, the following will get run unless you override it with a disk list:

 ceph orch apply osd --all-available-devices

So the new node is added and any unused clean disk becomes a new OSD.

gerritlib/gerrit.py.message: What causes the POLLPRI is still a mistery but based on what I read so far it is a notification, not a fatal error.

author.name: Jeremy Stanley
author.status: missing, presumed fed

gerritlib/gerrit.py.message:
An exception is, quite literally, a signal that an unexpected and unhandled event has occurred. If we don't normally expect POLLPRI on most systems, then when it shows up that's an exceptional event we don't know for sure how to handle (because we don't know what caused it to be set). If there is a subset of deployments where POLLPRI appears for known reasons, then we should if possible limit our handling of it to the platforms where we expect it, lest we incorrectly ignore an unrelated condition on the platforms where it is atypical. Printing a warning in the logs and continuing could, in some cases, be worse than terminating the process so the administrator can carefully inspect the system and connection before attempting to resume operation.

I do agree that equivalency in bitmask comparisons is rare (you should really only do it when you expect one and only one bit pattern match), so the switch to masking does seem like a good improvement to me.

On linux this seems to mean a very specific thing for tcp connections: there is out of band data to read. Since we don't know how to read out of band data in this code base I think the old behavior of raising an exception when that happens is correct for linux.

On OSX this POLLPRI behavior seems reproduceable but I'm not able to find out what it means on OSX. https://github.com/python-trio/trio/issues/61#issuecomment-546781689 implies it is not out of band though could be that the same flags are set.

I think to support this properly we need to understand what OSX is telling us here then properly read the info so that the event can be reset and raised again if necessary. On linux I think we should keep the old behavior unless we add out of band data processing. Otherwise we'll just spam the logs that there is out of band data there. The old behavior of erroring if we get something we don't expect seems safer.

author.name: Sorin Sbârnea
author.status: do not feed the troll 🥕

gerritlib/gerrit.py.message:
Please show me the specification that states that a program should raise an exception if POLLPRI bit is found on the event mask.

AFAIK, the `event == select.POLLIN` is a serious bug that should have never happen. I did low level programming for a good number of years to learn that you likely never check bit-marks using "==" operator, it is a recipe for failure.

There are bits that not even used and any presence of another bit would make the code choke.

Unless the original intent was to make it explode on other systems, that needs to go out.

I think that my original change was to replace == with &, but I was asked to add some debuging code, so we would better know what happened.

Even POSIX/SUS specification examples do not make use of == on bitmask test, see https://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/009695399/functions/poll.html

Whenever we decide to do something about POLLPRI or not, that is up to you, but fixing the incorrect == is a must.

I can think of a multitude of oob messages that could happen and that should not produce a HUP. The other side may say that it requires a keepalive, or that it is close to reaching its own buffer and will start to drop data. None of this indicate that you should not continue to read data when POLLIN is present.
Nit we use self.log elsewhere (I don't think we override the logger in the class instances so shouldn't matter).

Was this meant to be:

  (not IS_LINUX and event & select.POLLIN)

?

Unfortunately the machine types are versioned differently between various distros at the moment. deployment/undercloud/undercloud-upgrade.message: We should only do this after leap and not always.  A minor update on the undercloud uses 'upgrade'

I'm not really familiar with os-net-config, but shouldn't we check if the config is present before running the command? https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/313d8125cb8c0915aec12cf3ea7b925c8586a133/deployment/tripleo-packages/tripleo-packages-baremetal-puppet.yaml#L267-L271

I think you will need to set this fact upgrade_leapp_enabled, otherwise this task will fail with underfined parameter upgrade_leapp_enabled as this is defined in tripleo-packages and we don't run those tasks during the undercloud upgrade:
https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/313d8125cb8c0915aec12cf3ea7b925c8586a133/deployment/tripleo-packages/tripleo-packages-baremetal-puppet.yaml#L117-L122

I'm thinking a little bit more about this condition and I think it will never be met as we set LeappEnabled in the lifecycle environment files: https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/stable/train/environments/lifecycle/upgrade-prepare.yaml#L20 and this file is passed only for the overcloud upgrade. So even though you will include the UpgradeLeappEnabled this won't get executed because it will set to false. Also, as you have already run leapp you will be in RHEL8, so the conditions to set the parameter won't be met:

upgrade_leapp_enabled: >-
              {{ _upgradeLeappEnabled | bool and
                 ansible_facts['distribution'] == 'RedHat' and
                 ansible_facts['distribution_major_version'] is version('7', '==') }}

I think we need to find some way to detect if Leapp has been executed or not, or if os-net-config requires a trigger.

I agree with you. Introducing UpgradeLeappEnabled will require to set it to true on "openstack undercloud upgrade" However, operator doesn't run "openstack undercloud upgrade" every five minutes. I still thing it will cause no harm even on next minor update run.
LGTM if that works well for the previous tasks w/o properly configured DNS resolvers etc
